title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, titled "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act," defines terms such as historically women's public college or university and historic building or structure. The Act defines terms related to historic buildings, including those eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places or located within a designated historic district. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. Preservation and restoration grants for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings using funds from the National Historic Preservation Act for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Grants come with specific conditions. The Historic Preservation Act provides grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings. Grants come with conditions such as no alterations without the Secretary's approval and allowing public access for interpretive and educational purposes. Matching requirements apply to buildings and structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary may provide funds for grants related to historic buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places, National Historic Landmarks, or designated historic districts, with a requirement for the grantee to contribute 50% of the costs from non-Federal sources. Under the grant, non-Federal sources must contribute 50% of the program costs, with the Secretary providing the remaining 50%. In-kind contributions such as property or personnel services can also be used for the non-Federal share of costs. Funding provisions limit the amount available to $16,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006.
